title: How to Make a Paper Garland

steps.headline: Gather at least 10 pieces of construction paper.
steps.description: For variety, choose two different colors of paper, or even pick several different colors. Pick colors that are appropriate to the season or occasion -- red, green, and yellow for Christmas, or pastel colors for a baby shower or bridal shower.

steps.headline: Cut at least 3 strips of 2.5 inch by 10 inch (6.3 cm by 25.4 cm) paper from each piece of paper.
steps.description: Use a sturdy pair of scissors to cut equally-sized strips of paper from each piece of paper. You can adjust the size a bit according to your preference -- adjusting the width of the strips will make the garland loops wider and adjusting the length will make the loops longer.

steps.headline: Form one strip of paper into a loop.
steps.description: Simply create a loop by making the flat strip round, and touching the edges of the paper so that they are overlapping by at least 1 inch (2.5 cm). The most dependable way to make the strip stay in loop form is to glue the ends of the strip together and wait for the glue to dry before you move on. But if you don't have the time or patience to individually glue each garland, you can also tape the loops together using clear masking tape. If you're really pressed for time, you can even staple the ends of the loops together twice. Remember that if one loop falls apart, the garland will disconnect.

steps.headline: Connect another loop with the first loop.
steps.description: Now take another strip of paper and run it through the first loop until you connect the ends of that strip to form a second loop. Connect the ends of the second loop just as you did with the first loop. If you're going for alternating colors, make sure you pick a different color for the second loop.

steps.headline: Repeat this step until you've connected all of the loops.
steps.description: Continue running each strip of paper through the previous loop and then connecting it to make a loop until you've connected all of your loops and have created a paper garland of interlocking loops. If you'd like your garland to be a bit longer, just cut more strips of paper and create more loops until you're satisfied with the length.

steps.headline: Hang up your garland.
steps.description: Once your garland has been created, all you have to do is hang it up. You can drape the garland over a tree, a back patio, a column, or any piece of furniture. If you want to hang your garland up on the wall, hang the loops over a sturdy protruding nail.

steps.headline: Gather at least 10 pieces of cardstock paper.
steps.description: cardstock is a bit thicker and more durable than regular paper and will make your garland look more elegant. To create a fun and eye-catching garland, choose paper with a variety of designs, from pink and purple polka dots to striped or checkered green paper. Just pick a few patterns that will look good together. You can throw in some solid paper for variety.

steps.headline: Cut the paper into strips.
steps.description: Cut each piece of paper into 3-5 strips, depending on how big you want your circles to be. It will be easier to cut the circles if you cut the paper into strips first.

steps.headline: Cut circles from the paper.
steps.description: The garland will look best if the circles are a few different sizes. Cut circles that are at least three different sizes -- anywhere from a 3 inch to a 6 inch (7.6 cm to 15.2 cm) diameter will do. You don't have to use each color of paper equally, and you don't have to cut the same amount of each size of circle. The easiest way to cut the circles is to use a circular punch; you can also just trace a circular pattern on the back of each piece of paper and cut it with scissors.

steps.headline: Create your garland pattern.
steps.description: Lay down the circles in the order that you'd like them to appear on the garland. If you'd like to create a double-sided garland, then place the bottoms of two circles with the same size and pattern together. Lay them out in a way that creates variety and is visually appealing. Place this pattern near your sewing machine so you'll be easily able to feed it.

steps.headline: Sew the circles together.
steps.description: Pick a fun-colored thread for holding the garland together, such as red, and run a straight stitch down the center of each circle. Just place the first circle into the machine, place the needle down, and turn on the machine. Then continue to feed each circle into the machine, followed by the next one in the pattern you've chosen, until they are all connected by the thread. You can leave a few inches or centimeters between each circle, or spread them apart further or closer together. They don't need to be evenly spaced or sown right down the middle. As long as the circles are connected and catch the eye, you'll have a spectacular paper garland. Make an end stitch on the last circular shape.

steps.headline: Hang up your garland.
steps.description: Once you've created your garland, you can just hang it up by sticking a few thumbtacks in the wall and draping the thread over them. For more sturdiness, you can use nails for the same purpose. You can also drape the garlands over trees or furniture.

steps.headline: Gather at least 10 pieces of text weight paper.
steps.description: You'll need a few different colors to create the flower petals, and any shade of green to create the leaves. You can pick whatever colors are the most fun and visually appealing, but reds, yellows, or oranges will all look great. Text weight paper is a bit heavier than normal paper and will be easy to shape and curl. You should use 2-3 pieces of green paper -- the rest will be used for the flowers.

steps.headline: Trace flower patterns onto the paper.
steps.description: Create a template of a few different flowers with connected petals, and then trace this shape onto the paper designated for the petals. Then, create a template of a few different patterns with leaves and trace them onto the green paper. These patterns can be of any size, but the flowers should ideally be about the size of your hand, and the leaves should be about the size of three of your fingers.

steps.headline: Cut the patterns out of the paper.
steps.description: Use a sharp pair of scissors to cut each of the patterns out of the paper. You should have around twenty-five flowers and ten leaves by now.

steps.headline: Shape the flowers.
steps.description: Use a pair of scissors to curl the edges of the paper, just as you would curl ribbon. Just run the petals over the edge of the scissors until they curl. For variety, you can have some of the petals curling inward and some curling outward -- just alternate between curling the front of the paper and the back.

steps.headline: Shape the leaves.
steps.description: Fold the leaves in half to create a line along the middle of the leaves, and then curl them inward using the scissors. This will add texture and dimension to the leaves.

steps.headline: Create a pattern with the petals and leaves.
steps.description: Now place the flowers and leaves in a horizontal pattern that would create an eye-catching garland. The leaves will appear to the sides of the petals and don't need to alternate between each flower. You can repeat a pattern of colors or just arrange them at random.

steps.headline: Thread a needle through the shapes.
steps.description: Run baker's twine or very thick thread through a large needle, and use the needle to poke holes in the center of each petal and leaf. Then, run the threaded needle through the holes until you've connected all of the shapes with the thread. When you've run the thread through all of the shapes, just cut the thread and tie it in thick knots at both ends to hold the patterns together.

steps.headline: Add a small pompom (or beads) in the middle of the flower.
Hang up your garland.
steps.description: Now that you've created your stunning paper flower garland, you can hang it up by draping it over trees or other outdoor furniture, or hanging it on nails or thumb-tacks inside your home. You can wrap the garland around a banister or the trunk of a tree.

text: The Simple Paper Garland Gather at least 10 pieces of construction paper. For variety, choose two different colors of paper, or even pick several different colors. Pick colors that are appropriate to the season or occasion -- red, green, and yellow for Christmas, or pastel colors for a baby shower or bridal shower. Cut at least 3 strips of 2.5 inch by 10 inch (6.3 cm by 25.4 cm) paper from each piece of paper. Use a sturdy pair of scissors to cut equally-sized strips of paper from each piece of paper. You can adjust the size a bit according to your preference -- adjusting the width of the strips will make the garland loops wider and adjusting the length will make the loops longer. Form one strip of paper into a loop. Simply create a loop by making the flat strip round, and touching the edges of the paper so that they are overlapping by at least 1 inch (2.5 cm). The most dependable way to make the strip stay in loop form is to glue the ends of the strip together and wait for the glue to dry before you move on. But if you don't have the time or patience to individually glue each garland, you can also tape the loops together using clear masking tape. If you're really pressed for time, you can even staple the ends of the loops together twice. Remember that if one loop falls apart, the garland will disconnect. Connect another loop with the first loop. Now take another strip of paper and run it through the first loop until you connect the ends of that strip to form a second loop. Connect the ends of the second loop just as you did with the first loop. If you're going for alternating colors, make sure you pick a different color for the second loop. Repeat this step until you've connected all of the loops. Continue running each strip of paper through the previous loop and then connecting it to make a loop until you've connected all of your loops and have created a paper garland of interlocking loops. If you'd like your garland to be a bit longer, just cut more strips of paper and create more loops until you're satisfied with the length. Hang up your garland. Once your garland has been created, all you have to do is hang it up. You can drape the garland over a tree, a back patio, a column, or any piece of furniture. If you want to hang your garland up on the wall, hang the loops over a sturdy protruding nail. The Circular Paper Garland Gather at least 10 pieces of cardstock paper. cardstock is a bit thicker and more durable than regular paper and will make your garland look more elegant. To create a fun and eye-catching garland, choose paper with a variety of designs, from pink and purple polka dots to striped or checkered green paper. Just pick a few patterns that will look good together. You can throw in some solid paper for variety. Cut the paper into strips. Cut each piece of paper into 3-5 strips, depending on how big you want your circles to be. It will be easier to cut the circles if you cut the paper into strips first. Cut circles from the paper. The garland will look best if the circles are a few different sizes. Cut circles that are at least three different sizes -- anywhere from a 3 inch to a 6 inch (7.6 cm to 15.2 cm) diameter will do. You don't have to use each color of paper equally, and you don't have to cut the same amount of each size of circle. The easiest way to cut the circles is to use a circular punch; you can also just trace a circular pattern on the back of each piece of paper and cut it with scissors. Create your garland pattern. Lay down the circles in the order that you'd like them to appear on the garland. If you'd like to create a double-sided garland, then place the bottoms of two circles with the same size and pattern together. Lay them out in a way that creates variety and is visually appealing. Place this pattern near your sewing machine so you'll be easily able to feed it. Sew the circles together. Pick a fun-colored thread for holding the garland together, such as red, and run a straight stitch down the center of each circle. Just place the first circle into the machine, place the needle down, and turn on the machine. Then continue to feed each circle into the machine, followed by the next one in the pattern you've chosen, until they are all connected by the thread. You can leave a few inches or centimeters between each circle, or spread them apart further or closer together. They don't need to be evenly spaced or sown right down the middle. As long as the circles are connected and catch the eye, you'll have a spectacular paper garland. Make an end stitch on the last circular shape. Hang up your garland. Once you've created your garland, you can just hang it up by sticking a few thumbtacks in the wall and draping the thread over them. For more sturdiness, you can use nails for the same purpose. You can also drape the garlands over trees or furniture. The Paper Flower Garland Gather at least 10 pieces of text weight paper. You'll need a few different colors to create the flower petals, and any shade of green to create the leaves. You can pick whatever colors are the most fun and visually appealing, but reds, yellows, or oranges will all look great. Text weight paper is a bit heavier than normal paper and will be easy to shape and curl. You should use 2-3 pieces of green paper -- the rest will be used for the flowers. Trace flower patterns onto the paper. Create a template of a few different flowers with connected petals, and then trace this shape onto the paper designated for the petals. Then, create a template of a few different patterns with leaves and trace them onto the green paper. These patterns can be of any size, but the flowers should ideally be about the size of your hand, and the leaves should be about the size of three of your fingers. Cut the patterns out of the paper. Use a sharp pair of scissors to cut each of the patterns out of the paper. You should have around twenty-five flowers and ten leaves by now. Shape the flowers. Use a pair of scissors to curl the edges of the paper, just as you would curl ribbon. Just run the petals over the edge of the scissors until they curl. For variety, you can have some of the petals curling inward and some curling outward -- just alternate between curling the front of the paper and the back. Shape the leaves. Fold the leaves in half to create a line along the middle of the leaves, and then curl them inward using the scissors. This will add texture and dimension to the leaves. Create a pattern with the petals and leaves. Now place the flowers and leaves in a horizontal pattern that would create an eye-catching garland. The leaves will appear to the sides of the petals and don't need to alternate between each flower. You can repeat a pattern of colors or just arrange them at random. Thread a needle through the shapes. Run baker's twine or very thick thread through a large needle, and use the needle to poke holes in the center of each petal and leaf. Then, run the threaded needle through the holes until you've connected all of the shapes with the thread. When you've run the thread through all of the shapes, just cut the thread and tie it in thick knots at both ends to hold the patterns together. Add a small pompom (or beads) in the middle of the flower.  Hang up your garland. Now that you've created your stunning paper flower garland, you can hang it up by draping it over trees or other outdoor furniture, or hanging it on nails or thumb-tacks inside your home. You can wrap the garland around a banister or the trunk of a tree.
sentences: The Simple Paper Garland Gather at least 10 pieces of construction paper.
For variety, choose two different colors of paper, or even pick several different colors.
Pick colors that are appropriate to the season or occasion -- red, green, and yellow for Christmas, or pastel colors for a baby shower or bridal shower.
Cut at least 3 strips of 2.5 inch by 10 inch (6.3 cm by 25.4 cm) paper from each piece of paper.
Use a sturdy pair of scissors to cut equally-sized strips of paper from each piece of paper.
You can adjust the size a bit according to your preference -- adjusting the width of the strips will make the garland loops wider and adjusting the length will make the loops longer.
Form one strip of paper into a loop.
Simply create a loop by making the flat strip round, and touching the edges of the paper so that they are overlapping by at least 1 inch (2.5 cm).
The most dependable way to make the strip stay in loop form is to glue the ends of the strip together and wait for the glue to dry before you move on.
But if you don't have the time or patience to individually glue each garland, you can also tape the loops together using clear masking tape.
If you're really pressed for time, you can even staple the ends of the loops together twice.
Remember that if one loop falls apart, the garland will disconnect.
Connect another loop with the first loop.
Now take another strip of paper and run it through the first loop until you connect the ends of that strip to form a second loop.
Connect the ends of the second loop just as you did with the first loop.
If you're going for alternating colors, make sure you pick a different color for the second loop.
Repeat this step until you've connected all of the loops.
Continue running each strip of paper through the previous loop and then connecting it to make a loop until you've connected all of your loops and have created a paper garland of interlocking loops.
If you'd like your garland to be a bit longer, just cut more strips of paper and create more loops until you're satisfied with the length.
Hang up your garland.
Once your garland has been created, all you have to do is hang it up.
You can drape the garland over a tree, a back patio, a column, or any piece of furniture.
If you want to hang your garland up on the wall, hang the loops over a sturdy protruding nail.
The Circular Paper Garland Gather at least 10 pieces of cardstock paper.
cardstock is a bit thicker and more durable than regular paper and will make your garland look more elegant.
To create a fun and eye-catching garland, choose paper with a variety of designs, from pink and purple polka dots to striped or checkered green paper.
Just pick a few patterns that will look good together.
You can throw in some solid paper for variety.
Cut the paper into strips.
Cut each piece of paper into 3-5 strips, depending on how big you want your circles to be.
It will be easier to cut the circles if you cut the paper into strips first.
Cut circles from the paper.
The garland will look best if the circles are a few different sizes.
Cut circles that are at least three different sizes -- anywhere from a 3 inch to a 6 inch (7.6 cm to 15.2 cm) diameter will do.
You don't have to use each color of paper equally, and you don't have to cut the same amount of each size of circle.
The easiest way to cut the circles is to use a circular punch; you can also just trace a circular pattern on the back of each piece of paper and cut it with scissors.
Create your garland pattern.
Lay down the circles in the order that you'd like them to appear on the garland.
If you'd like to create a double-sided garland, then place the bottoms of two circles with the same size and pattern together.
Lay them out in a way that creates variety and is visually appealing.
Place this pattern near your sewing machine so you'll be easily able to feed it.
Sew the circles together.
Pick a fun-colored thread for holding the garland together, such as red, and run a straight stitch down the center of each circle.
Just place the first circle into the machine, place the needle down, and turn on the machine.
Then continue to feed each circle into the machine, followed by the next one in the pattern you've chosen, until they are all connected by the thread.
You can leave a few inches or centimeters between each circle, or spread them apart further or closer together.
They don't need to be evenly spaced or sown right down the middle.
As long as the circles are connected and catch the eye, you'll have a spectacular paper garland.
Make an end stitch on the last circular shape.
Hang up your garland.
Once you've created your garland, you can just hang it up by sticking a few thumbtacks in the wall and draping the thread over them.
For more sturdiness, you can use nails for the same purpose.
You can also drape the garlands over trees or furniture.
The Paper Flower Garland Gather at least 10 pieces of text weight paper.
You'll need a few different colors to create the flower petals, and any shade of green to create the leaves.
You can pick whatever colors are the most fun and visually appealing, but reds, yellows, or oranges will all look great.
Text weight paper is a bit heavier than normal paper and will be easy to shape and curl.
You should use 2-3 pieces of green paper -- the rest will be used for the flowers.
Trace flower patterns onto the paper.
Create a template of a few different flowers with connected petals, and then trace this shape onto the paper designated for the petals.
Then, create a template of a few different patterns with leaves and trace them onto the green paper.
These patterns can be of any size, but the flowers should ideally be about the size of your hand, and the leaves should be about the size of three of your fingers.
Cut the patterns out of the paper.
Use a sharp pair of scissors to cut each of the patterns out of the paper.
You should have around twenty-five flowers and ten leaves by now.
Shape the flowers.
Use a pair of scissors to curl the edges of the paper, just as you would curl ribbon.
Just run the petals over the edge of the scissors until they curl.
For variety, you can have some of the petals curling inward and some curling outward -- just alternate between curling the front of the paper and the back.
Shape the leaves.
Fold the leaves in half to create a line along the middle of the leaves, and then curl them inward using the scissors.
This will add texture and dimension to the leaves.
Create a pattern with the petals and leaves.
Now place the flowers and leaves in a horizontal pattern that would create an eye-catching garland.
The leaves will appear to the sides of the petals and don't need to alternate between each flower.
You can repeat a pattern of colors or just arrange them at random.
Thread a needle through the shapes.
Run baker's twine or very thick thread through a large needle, and use the needle to poke holes in the center of each petal and leaf.
Then, run the threaded needle through the holes until you've connected all of the shapes with the thread.
When you've run the thread through all of the shapes, just cut the thread and tie it in thick knots at both ends to hold the patterns together.
Add a small pompom (or beads) in the middle of the flower.
Hang up your garland.
Now that you've created your stunning paper flower garland, you can hang it up by draping it over trees or other outdoor furniture, or hanging it on nails or thumb-tacks inside your home.
You can wrap the garland around a banister or the trunk of a tree.
